### Get

```
$ ./bin/pulsar-admin namespaces get-delayed-delivery public/default

{
  "tickTime" : 1000,
  "active" : true
}
```

### Set

```
$ ./bin/pulsar-admin namespaces set-delayed-delivery public/default --enable --time 2s
```

> i have met this problem also....
> finally, i find when use Key_Shared subscription mode, the producer must set like this:
> ` private Producer<Integer> createProducer(String topic, boolean enableBatch) throws PulsarClientException { Producer<Integer> producer = null; if (enableBatch) { producer = pulsarClient.newProducer(Schema.INT32) .topic(topic) .enableBatching(true) .batcherBuilder(BatcherBuilder.KEY_BASED) .create(); } else { producer = pulsarClient.newProducer(Schema.INT32) .topic(topic) .enableBatching(false) .create(); } return producer; }`
> because producer enable batching by default, so you must set batcherBuilder(BatcherBuilder.KEY_BASED) when use Key_Shared mode.

Thank you, this solves my problem.
Can you give me a test code? It seems that it is difficult for me to reproduce this problem locally. including some configurations of the cluster. @TC-oKozlov

Hello! We started using Pulsar instead of Kafka in our system, and currently facing the same issue, when few subscriptions (like 1 - 3 of 30) stop receiving messages, and they get stuck in a backlog, until either a subscriber, or pulsar proxy restarted. 

We are using version 2.4.2, with 3 brokers in a cluster. Issue appears pretty often, like 3 - 6 times in a day. Stats also attached. Hope this issue can be fixed or at least hope there can be any workaround except of force deleting kube pods with subscriptions to make them reconnect. We used Kafka to handle some critical parts of our system, unfortunately we can't rely on Pulsar without having simplest consumer - producer scenario work well. Thank you!

[topic-stats-internal.txt](https://github.com/apache/pulsar/files/4006279/stats-internal.txt)
[topic-stats.txt](https://github.com/apache/pulsar/files/4006280/stats.txt)

For anyone who is interested in this topic, here is the summary of it.

I have reached out to both the owners of `pulsar-client-dotnet` and `dotpulsar` about contributing their pulsar client library back to the community. The maintainer of `dotpulsar` is interested in moving the project to the ASF. They have started the email thread for discussing the contribution. 

https://lists.apache.org/thread.html/8ebe35027d818e595eec322da26a3f392324ec3d86c4c1b12b1ff498%40%3Cdev.pulsar.apache.org%3E

Everyone is welcome to chime in the topic and give the feedback and thoughts in that email thread.

Happy new year!

I am so sorry for the late reply. I tested in cluster mode and did not reproduce your problem. My test environment, 3 brokers, 2 function_worker, uses Ubuntu 16.04.6 LTS and pulsar version 2.4.2. The command is as follows:

Install the pulsar client on each function_worker:

```
pip install pulsar-client
```

Create and start function

```
./bin/pulsar-admin functions create --py /root/test-function/word_function.py --classname word_function.WordCountFunction --tenant public --namespace default --name excfunc --inputs test1 --output test2
```

The content of word_function.py, 

```
from pulsar import Function

# The classic ExclamationFunction that appends an exclamation at the end
# of the input
class WordCountFunction(Function):
    def __init__(self):
        pass

    def process(self, input, context):
        words = input.split()
        for word in words:
            context.incr_counter(word, 1)
            context.get_logger().info("The value is " + str(context.get_counter(word)))
        return input + "!"
```

If you have any questions, please ping me. @thlautenschlaeger Can you provide more context information if possible?

@tuteng could you help check removed parameters in the `broker.conf` file? Thank you.

I found **JWT_TOKEN** is good enough, this issue will be closed.

For docker run command:
```
export JWT_TOKEN=`cat token-value.txt`
```

For kubernetes cluster:
```
name: JWT_TOKEN
valueFrom:
  secretKeyRef:
    name: token-name
    key: token-value.txt
```

cd pulsar-client-cpp
./pulsar-test-service-start.sh
cd python

```
bin/pulsar-admin topics delete compaction_xxxx
```

The delete operation is executed successfully.
